headline: Pickled Onions
description: Pickled red onions in red wine vinegar are so easy to make at home. This tangy condiment is delicious on sandwiches, burgers, salads, and more.
name: Pickled Onions

recipeInstructions.text: Combine onion, both vinegars, salt, and sugar in a saucepan over medium-high heat; bring to a boil. Remove from the heat and allow mixture to steep until onion is tender, about 20 minutes.
Cool for at least 30 minutes, then strain and serve.

review.reviewBody: I liked this recipe because it was easy but I added peppercorns
I love these onions. I cut back on the salt though.
WAY too much salt and not enough sugar,

I loved this but like others, I found it a little too vinegary. And I love vinegar. I'll add a little more sugar next time. And I thinly sliced these instead of finely chopping them. But a great base recipe.
Way too much salt. Reverse the proportions.
Way too salty for my taste. I was thinking it was a lot of salt while adding, but decided to stick with the directions. Should have gone with my gut!
This was so easy and turned out delicious

I made these a week ago, and they get better every day. Really delicious. This recipe is a keeper. I did reduce the salt to 1/2 tsp and increased the sugar to 4 tbsp as other had recommended. I will definitely be making this again.

I used yellow onions instead of red, cut half and sliced ~1/4 inch. I substituted the same volume of honey as white sugar. 1/4 cup each of red wine vinegar and balsamic vinegar. After simmering, I added a pinch each of ground black pepper, turmeric, and parsley.

omg, so delicious! I used sweet onion just because that's my preference. Used, 1/2 tsp. salt and 2 tbsp. sugar. I also prefered onion slices. I use them in burrito bowls, burgers, salads. super easy and ready in no time!
great on flatbread as a garnish with smoked chicken, shredded gouda, on a flatbread that was brushed with garlic butter. Bake until light golden then drizzle balsamic glaze

I made this recipe exactly by the original. It came out great but next time I’d back off the salt just a lil but for a quick pickle the family loved it for our falafels!! I’ll definitely be making this again!
Delicious!! Way too much salt for us though, we reduced the salt to one tsp.
Quick and easy to make. Just the right amount of tang.
Easy to make and so good. An excellent condiment for hamburgers and brats.

OK, so I doubled the recipe so my amounts will reflect that. Love this recipe super easy. I made the following changes: six whole cloves of garlic, about 18 peppercorns and the same Number of allspice berries (I was shooting for three of each in the half pint jars I was making). I do a lot of canning and wasn’t sure if I was going to process this in a hot bath or not but just to be on the safe side I added the appropriate amount of pickle crisp from ball products. These turned out wonderfully and I’m asked my friends and family to make them some next time I’m buying red onions in bulk.
This was a great recipe. It was quick and easy to make. I doubled the recipe and made a quart jar full.
Wayyyyy too much salt. Must have been a typo. Had to throw away.
I Made them!!! But i doubled the order. I’m waiting patiently to add them on my black sea bass fish
Thought it would be like the pickled onions we had down south a year ago. But it was not . This was horrible, too much vinegar.

This is how I make mine, *no* sugar added! Blanch your sliced yellow or white onions in boiling water for a few seconds. Rinse with cold water and drain. Add them to your preferred container with sliced jarred or cannned beets along with the beet juice and apple cider vinegar to taste and refrigerate. That's it. The beets give the onions a beautiful pink color and a little sweetness. *No* salt. I love to use these on my homemade hummus. A little sumac oil on top.

I would give this a 5 star except it was too salty. With that being said I will definitely make these again. I made the recipe as is, with sea salt. Next time I will use Kosher and probably increase the sugar. I added bay leaf, coriander and marjoram and I will definitely do that again.
Add 3-4 garlic cloves per single batch and they are even better! Love this recipe!
my mom LOVED it
Good recipe. The onions are pickled, but still crispy. Make sure to stir onions a few times, so that all the onions sit in the vinegar brine. Delicious on pulled pork sandwiches!

I made this recipe exactly as stated and my husband and I love it. My sister uses pickled onions on her avacado toast and I LOVED it so needed a recipe for them and this is it! We've used it on the aforementioned avacado toast and on burgers, so delicious. Can't wait to try on more foods!
Way too much salt.

Used one red onion cut in half and sliced. Used a bottle of red wine vinegar and approximated other ingredients. Added red pepper flakes and tarragon and garlic. Didn’t boil it. Stuck it in a used mayonnaise jar and left it in the refrigerator over night. Turned out fine.

I’m addicted to Panara’s arugula and steak sandwich which comes smothered in pickled red onions. I decided to try and make some pickled onions so I can add them to burgers and tacos too. I used this recipe but changed the red wine vinegar to apple cider vinegar as other reviewers recommended and because I love ACV. I tasted after a few hours and they were no where near sweet enough so I added a couple heaping tablespoons of sugar. I continued tasting over the next couple of days and while the flavor was better, they were a lot crunchier than I wanted. I found some other recipes where the onions are blanched first, so I’ll try doing that next time.

I made this exactly as written. It is way too salty. I LOVE salt, in an unhealthy way, but this will make you cough it's so salty. I will try it with half as much next time. The other flavors are great. I gave it four starts because it is definitely worth making, just with less salt.
These are great, but I prefer them with a few changes. I cut the onion into slivers about 1 inch long. Use 1-1/2 tsp salt, not tablespoons and replace red wine vinegar with white wine vinegar.
Easy, quick and delicious recipe. I however, added additional sugar to taste. Overall, a handy side dish that packs a good amount of flavor.
I made a jar for me and one for my mom. They’re both almost gone so I will definitely be making more!

Oh, my goodness, this could easily become a new addiction! After reading reviews, I cut the salt in half, upped the sugar to 4 Tbsp, used apple cider vinegar. Even with half the salt, I still found them a tad too salty, but still amazing!! I can hardly wait to finish this batch, so I can make more. Thanks for the great recipe.
Great recipe!!
I cut back a little on the vinegar, added a little water.
Made exactly many times. Great on a Greek salad or burgers.
Excellent on Avacadobtoast!!
So quick and easy - very delicious on salad!
I expected the flavor to be more along the lines of other pickled vegetables—a nice tangy vinegar flavor with a balanced sweetness, but this was nothing but salty water with a sharp vinegar bite.
Simple, tasty, just what my tacos needed. Perfect!
It was edible, but I would not make this again. Way too salty. I have only had these in restaurants and I am used to them being a little sweet with an undetectable level of salt.
So good and so easy to do. I love the red wine vinegar rather than white vinegar alone.

no changes, have made many times doubled, +
made boiled yuca & onions
enjoyed very much good on a turkey sandwich too
Definitely reduce the salt. Too salty.
Love love this recipe!
Absolutely loved it! I used apple cider vinegar instead of balsamic only because I didn’t have the balsamic. Easy recipe and very delicious. Use nightly in my salad-gives extra flavor.
quick and easy
For pickled onions, these are great! So easy to make, and they are definitely "pickled"!! These will get eaten in my home, no doubt, but I discovered I am looking for SWEET pickled onions.

We love these. I have tried both red wine vinegar and apple cider vinegar and my crew prefers the apple cider vinegar. We toss these on pork street tacos- absolutely delicious! We have some fairly picky eaters, but our son who picks onions out of his food can’t get enough of the street tacos, and doesn’t go lightly on the onions.

Absoluletly a great addition to salads and sandwiches. Very peasy to make. I have developed the habit of keeping a mason jar in fridge most of time. I do keep the recipe scotch taped to the inside of kitchen cabinet until my brain has it memorized.
I added yellow mustard seed and celery seed, about ½ the salt, used cider vinegar. Yum!
No changes! It’s perfect
Easy and delicious. But... a bit salty for my taste. On my second round I cut the salt to 2/3 tbsp and doubled the sugar. Perfect!
Easy and Delicious
1tsp of salt, 4Tbs of sugar.
I too changed the recipe...way too much salt and not enough sugar! Added 2 Tblspns of sugar and 1/2 Tsp salt. Also used apple cider vinegar...much better! I am not a big salt person.
These are a great addition to Mexican food to cut through the spice. Tasted great on my veggie tacos!
The salt & sugar is WAY off. I’ve added 3 times the sugar & still too salty.
So easy and turned out great!
Super easy and tasty! My onion was pretty big so I doubled the vinegar and added 1/4 cup of water. Came out perfectly!
If I switch the salt and sugar measurements, this recipe is [perfect.

TOO SALTY! I wish I had read reviews before I made this. I love pickled onions, I've made them before but couldn't find my recipe. I tried this and only after I dumped the 1T of salt did I think, "That seemed like a LOT". Too late, I tried to get some of it out but it was just too salty. I did increase the sugar too, thought it might balance it out, but in the end I had to throw this away. I'm disappointed people rate recipes highly and then comment that they made huge changes to the recipe, that rating is deceptive! I trust the star ratings to believe a recipe will be good. This recipe, as it is written, is not good.
Delicious with changes in ingredients. 1/2 tbs salt, 3 tbs sugar, 1/4 cup red wine vinegar, 1/4 cup apple cider vinegar
Thinly sliced red onion , not finely chopped.
Smashing! Will I make these again? YES!! No changes required, as written is perfect.
Made this as directed 1st time, but second time I omitted the white vinegar and preferred it with just red wine vinegar.
Ok. VERY salty! Next time we will cut way back on salt

These were fantastic on the street tacos that I made this weekend. The only changes that I made were: 1. I split the 1/2 cup of red wine vinegar up and used 1/4 cup of red wine vinegar and 1/4 cup of apple cider vinegar, and 2. I increased the sugar to 1 tablespoon. With both of these changes, they were absolutely perfect. My friends and family were eating the onions by themselves and trying to come up with ideas of other foods that they could put them on.
Fun recipe and tasty to boot. makes a good sweet and tangy addition to any dish.
Way too salty. I like vinegar but these were too much. Needs more sugar. Maybe I need sweet pickled onions.
Quick, Easy and delicious!
I sliced my onions not chopped. I dissolved Kosher salt and sugar in the vinegar then added the onions and stored in the fridge. I stirred them 3 times a day. I love pickled onions.
Too salty! I was looking for a bit sweeter.
I made it with apple cider vinegar and some white wine vinegar. I found it too salty.
Delicious!
Who knew these were so easy to make? A very good thing because they were a big hit!
I used rice vinegar instead and I have used this as a condiment in many Asian dishes.
Went perfectly with the beef bulgogi ?
A little salty to me, might cut the salt in half next time.
Way, way too much salt. I wish I would have seen previous reviews that agreed. I also sliced the onions instead of chopping.
After taking it off of the heat I put a lid on it for the 20 minutes. Incase anyone was confused (as I was) on what steep meant in this particular case. Delicious! Definitely a new favorite.
I will them again but leave out the salt, after reading more recipes I found that they didn't call for salt.
The seasonings are off. I found it too salty and too tangy.
Love these! Eat them right out of the jar. I am going to bump up the sugar slightly next time.
This is so incredibly salty that it is inedible. I threw it out.
Great onions.....I added a few peppercorns, I would recommend cutting back on the salt. Far to salty for my taste.

This is a simple and great recipe! I made a few minor changes... I used apple cider vinegar instead of the red wine vinegar, and sherry wine vinegar in place of white (I was out of white). I did cut the salt a little and added about 1.5T of honey. I also only steeped for about 10-12 min. They are perfect! Not too soft, not too much pucker. I'm not an onion person but was making these to pair with a roasted corn relish for tacos, and I could just eat it as is! Who needs the taco ;)
I found it to be too salty with 1 1/2 Tbls. of salt. I added more sugar, another onion and more vinegar to tone it down but still seemed too salty. I'll cut way back on the salt next time.
made this tonight to have with my steak and I may never make mushrooms again....awesome
Tasty and attractive as a burger topping, but my family and I found it too salty. I will be halving the amount of salt, but will definitely make this again!
This is way to much vinegar and not enough sugar. I wouldn't make again.

Really easy to make and the color is beautiful. I did alter the amount of sugar adding 3 tablespoons and lessened the salt to 1 teaspoon because we are all hypertensive. Next time I'll increase the sugar to 4 tablespoons and add a pinch of red pepper flakes. Great on carnitas!

This was so easy and the onions were great. Had them on a pizza with bbq pork and hatch chiles and they gave a really nice acidic pop. (My pizza loving boyfriend deemed it the best pizza he has ever had and he eats a lot of pizza.)

This makes an excellent topping for tacos. this recipe does come out a bit sour, which some people love, and others want to sweeten up. A nice variation is to use a combination of orange and lime juice on the blanched onion instead of vinegar (with salt and sugar to taste) - or better yet Seville/bitter orange juice, which is what is used for the original version in Yucatan. believe it or not, it is available in bottles at Walmart in Hispanic areas - usually Badia brand.
I love making these to serve on tacos on in sandwiches. They last for weeks in the fridge!

I first looked for this recipe after enjoying something similar in a restaurant, and this makes the perfect compliment to a shredded bbq chicken/pork sandwich! So simple yet so good! Recipe perfect as-is.

I made it exactly as in the recipe and it is tangy but a great addition to a spinach salad with a warm bacon vinaigrette. I also got the warm bacon vinaigrette recipe here too. They are great on sandwiches and even as a tipping on a steak or marinated chicken breasts. Love them.
I followed the recipe ingredients exacty, but I made it in the microwave- they were delicious. I served them with smoked salmon, capers and a mustard sauce on pumpernickel bread! Yum!!
